awd_titl_txt: SNM-IS: Scalable Biomineralization of Functional Oxide Nanoparticles and Nanostructures for Environmental and Energy Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project seeks to create a scalable, green, continuous process for biomineralization of nanoparticles directly from aqueous solutions at room temperature and to create structured catalysts for automotive and other industrial applications. Biomineralization is the process by which biological systems produce inorganic minerals, which display nanostructured features that are otherwise difficult to achieve. Nanostructured minerals are essential components in a number of industrially-important processes and products, in which control over the particle size is key to performance. As one example, certain nanostructured minerals, such as ceria, are used in automobile emission control, to remove carbon monoxide and other environmentally harmful exhaust gases. Current industrial methods for nanostructured ceria production often require high temperatures, high pressures and toxic solvents, thus limiting their utility. This research project involves studying methods to overcome these limitations by engineering enzymes as biocatalysts for the large-scale production of nanostructured ceria. The researchers on this project collaborate with researchers at Cerion, an industrial partner, to understand industrial-scale production issues. This project provides a unique, cross-disciplinary educational opportunity for U.S. graduate and undergraduate students to gain training in synthetic biology, nanoparticle manufacturing and catalysis. It also provides opportunities to partner with leading international institutes such as the Cardiff Catalysis Institute which will enable U.S. students to learn state-of-the-art production and characterization methods. This project will lead to a new, environmentally-friendly process to produce high-value materials and demonstrate their enhanced performance in consumer products such as automobiles. 

The goal of this research is to develop a robust, green and flexible platform for the high-yield enzymatic synthesis of size-controlled ceria and ceria-zirconia nanoparticles directly from aqueous solutions at room temperature, and to integrate these materials into structured catalyst platforms. The approach is to study and develop engineered silicatein, the enzyme responsible for silica mineralization in sea sponges, to control mineralization of both ceria and ceria-zirconia in a size range, less than 2 nm, that enables functional superiority in primary catalytic applications as compared to conventional chemically-synthesized nanoceria. The fundamental technical barriers to scalable, green nanomanufacturing of these materials are overcome by using directed evolution in engineering enzymes with enhanced nanoceria synthesis rates and integrating them into immobilized enzyme biocatalysts for large-scale nanoceria production. The unique advantages of biomineralization enables the synthesis of smaller, more homogeneous nanoparticles and the direct, enzymatic synthesis of nanomaterials on structured support materials for their integration into catalytic nanosystems. Ultimately, the ability to produce nanoceria directly from aqueous solutions and to control particle size will create the next generation of these important classes of new, emergent nanomaterials at a cost and scale compatible with the needs of industry.

por.por_cntn:
Our work has focused on creating scalable, continuous processes to (1) recover critical minerals using a biologically-inspired approach, (2) create advanced, functional materials from recovered critical minerals using biomineralization and (3) integrate recovered and upgraded materials into end-use applications in advanced manufacturing. Biomineralization is the process by which biological systems convert inorganic ions in solution into solid metal oxides or other inorganic materials. In one key example of outcomes from our work, we demonstrated that recovery of ceria and ceria-zirconia solid solutions (i.e., nanoceria) provide a new stream of upgraded materials with improved catalytic properties for use in industrial products manufacturing. In another key example of outcomes of our work, we identified microbial systems capable of direct, selective lithium recovery from simulated brines, enabling production of high-purity lithium nanoparticles for downstream applications. In general, current chemical routes to nanomaterials synthesis often require high temperatures, high pressures and toxic solvents, thereby limiting their scalability. Our work has demonstrated how biomineralization can enable scalable nanomanufacturing to overcome these limitations, thereby allowing improved recovery of critical minerals in a form useful for industrial application. 

The intellectual merit of our approach is through development of an engineered enzyme silicatein, which is responsible for silica mineralization in sea sponges, as a platform to control mineralization of both ceria and ceria- in a size range (< 2 nm) that enables functional superiority in primary catalytic applications as compared to conventional chemically-synthesized nanoceria. Our work led to a greater understanding of the processs by which silicatein evolves flexibility to biomineralize different classes of metal oxides, as well as how silicatein can be used in engineered microbial systems to improve synthesized material properties. Of note, we partnered with the US Air Force Academy (USAFA) to implement use of engineered silicatein as a tool to enhance mechanical properties of mineralized concrete. The improved materials (i.e., bio-bricks) formed the basis for methods that could be used to rapidly synthesize materials in austere forward environments. We also expanded this work to include an enzyme (smCSE) discovered by our group to produce metal selenide and metal sulfide nanocrystals as another example of how biomineralization, and generated a series of functional materials using smCSE to complement our work with silicatein. We also pursued further microbial discovery applications in efforts to find new proteins with unique biomineralization capabilities. This led to identification of a bacterially-derived protein capable of mineralizing lithium hydroxide directly from simulated brines; this is of key importance in downstream battery manufacturing and recycling processes as a scalable alternative to filtration-based methods.

Collectively, our work has eliminated barriers to demonstrate scalable nanomanufacturing of critical materials using a combination of directed evolution and bioprospecting, as well as integration of biomineralized materials into end-use applications validated for improved performance. Furthermore, the unique advantages of biomineralization enable the synthesis of smaller and more homogeneous particles and the direct, enzymatic synthesis of nanomaterials on structured support materials for their integration into systems for enhanced catalytic applications. We ultimately envision the ability to control size and produce nanomaterials directly from aqueous solutions will have a transformative impact to create the next generation of these important classes of new, emergent nanomaterials at a cost and scale for a range of critical minerals of increasing importance.

Our work directly addresses the challenge of scalable nanomanufacturing by working directly with external partners such as the US Air Force Academy industry to develop biomineralization strategies that are not only successful at a laboratory scale, but also realizable in end-use applications at scale. This is uniquely possible through biomineralization, in which scalable synthesis at ambient temperature is possible, unlike current chemical and industrial synthesis methods. We view this as the beginning of broader biomining strategies to recover critical minerals and upgrade them to functional nanomaterials that harness the power of biology to remove environmentally unfriendly chemical synthesis methods. Furthermore, in working with internationally recognized leaders at the Cardiff Catalysis Institute in the area of heterogeneous catalysis, the US Air Force Academy and others, we have been able to address key, future needs in scalable nanomanufacturing that will have a direct impact on driving the development of new catalytic applications integrating biomineralized nanomaterials.
